TopicTitle: [WIN/MAC/LINUX] KSP Trajectory Optimization Tool v1.6.9 [New MATLAB Version!]

Articles.Content: Yes, each of the bodies has some rotational offset at T = 0. I had to find this information from within ksp itself. It's not easily determined experimentally.

4 minutes ago, Arrowstar said:

Yes, each of the bodies has some rotational offset at T = 0. I had to find this information from within ksp itself. It's not easily determined experimentally. 

Yes I know, that is why I am asking the question. But what is the rotational offset relative to I already know the offset but what I don't know is what it is relative to.  (and if you say the X axis I am going to scream)

1 minute ago, mcirish3 said:

Yes I know, that is why I am asking the question. But what is the rotational offset relative to I already know the offset but what I don't know is what it is relative to.  (and if you say the X axis I am going to scream)

"The x axis."

Seriously though: Pretend with me for a second that the static, non-rotating X, Y, and Z axes of the universe and the rotating X, Y, Z axis of Kerbin are exactly lined up at T = 0.  Right on top of each other now.  Okay, now, rotate Kerbin by the amount shown in the bodies.ini file about Kerbin's rotation axis (which in KSP is always +Z).  This new orientation of Kerbin is how Kerbin is actually rotated at T = 0. So the rotini variable really just describes the orientation of the planet's coordinate system with respect to the universe's coordinate system at T = 0.

Does that make sense?

48 minutes ago, Arrowstar said:

"The x axis."

Seriously though: Pretend with me for a second that the static, non-rotating X, Y, and Z axes of the universe and the rotating X, Y, Z axis of Kerbin are exactly lined up at T = 0.  Right on top of each other now.  Okay, now, rotate Kerbin by the amount shown in the bodies.ini file about Kerbin's rotation axis (which in KSP is always +Z).  This new orientation of Kerbin is how Kerbin is actually rotated at T = 0. So the rotini variable really just describes the orientation of the planet's coordinate system with respect to the universe's coordinate system at T = 0.

Does that make sense?

Yes, and I was already there.  My question is; does the non-rotating X, Y, and Z  axes of the KSP universe at T=0 have the X Axis passing directly through the the center of Kerbin with its origin directly at the center of Sol at that moment, and if not where is it relative to kerbin at that moment?

Edited January 26, 2016 by mcirish3

Oh, you're just looking for the position vector of Kerbin (in a Sol-centered reference frame) at T = 0?

I honestly don't know.  Gaiiden, can you do the orbit elements -> position vector conversion?

52 minutes ago, Arrowstar said:

I honestly don't know.  Gaiiden, can you do the orbit elements -> position vector conversion?

Uhhhhhhhhhhhhh

Nope. To be honest I'm not entirely sure what he's looking for myself. Even if I did I doubt my pre-algebraic level of math skills could fully comprehend it That's not to say I never learned algebra, I just mostly forgot it all

OK, so now that at least one of you understand what I am talking about.  Here is what I think, and was only seeking confirmation on;

The  the non-rotating X, Y, and Z  axes of the KSP universe at T=0 does have the X Axis passing directly through the the center of Kerbin and that Kerbin's local coordinate system is rotate 90 (just like the INI file states) The reason I state that, is that T=0 happens to correspond exactly to the first sunset on Kerbin at coordinate 0o 0' 0" latitude, 0o 0' 0" longitude.    What is messing with me is the mean anomaly of Kerbin = actual anomaly of Kerbin( since it is a circular orbit) but if what I said above is true then at T=0 it should be 0 not 179.908753682 at epoch (sec) 0 as is state int the INI data Gaiiden shared upstream in this thread.

@Gaiiden FYI the sidereal rotation for kerbin was wrong in the INI dat you gave me.  It should be 21549.4251830898 (sec).

Also by the way no one seems to know that answer to this question.

Edited January 26, 2016 by mcirish3

The reason I am so determined to find out for sure is because it is the last piece a puzzle.   The puzzle being two fold.  

1. Being able to have a accurate local clock on all the planets. (something no one can do now.)

 2. More usefully being able, on all the planets and moons with atmospheres, to predict for any time, Latitude, longitude, and altitude the exact ambient temperature, which would then give you the exact local density.  which means you could infact calculate the full optimally fuel efficient, just short of burning up your ship, launch and landing trajectory for any and all ship designs. (Something some have gotten close to doing with other methods but this would be the ultimate method)

3 hours ago, Gaiiden said:

Hrm, weird. I though the file I gave you was from a recent KSPTOT version but apparently not. I checked another more recently-created bodies file I didn't give you because it was filled with extra planetary body info (from Outer Planets Mod) and Kerbin's rotperiod is correctly listed at 21549.425183090 (the one I gave you had the solar day time)

Sorry about that. Here's the more recent file:

 

It is ok, it was the only discrepancy I found out side of the mean anomaly.   And I think the mean anomaly is only off by a very small amount.   @ElWanderer said something HERE that makes me think it should be 180o instead of 179.908753682  since it is really PI.  So problem solved.  well not quite but the last of my larger questions is answered which means I can finally really get down to work.
look forward to seeing what you cook up with this
Thank you both for the help

9 hours ago, mcirish3 said:

It is ok, it was the only discrepancy I found out side of the mean anomaly.   And I think the mean anomaly is only off by a very small amount.   @ElWanderer said something HERE that makes me think it should be 180o instead of 179.908753682  since it is really PI.  So problem solved.  well not quite but the last of my larger questions is answered which means I can finally really get down to work.

I said 180° because (a) it's a round number and (b) the wiki says 3.14 radians, but also tends to round values to 2d.p. (e.g. parts with mass 0.025t are shown in the wiki as having a mass of 0.03t) so I assumed the value was really pi. If you've found a slightly different value in the game's data files, I'd probably trust that, unless testing shows otherwise.

4 hours ago, ElWanderer said:

I said 180° because (a) it's a round number and (b) the wiki says 3.14 radians, but also tends to round values to 2d.p. (e.g. parts with mass 0.025t are shown in the wiki as having a mass of 0.03t) so I assumed the value was really pi. If you've found a slightly different value in the game's data files, I'd probably trust that, unless testing shows otherwise.

Well there is also the fact that Sunset at 0,0,0 on kerbin happens exactly at T=0.  And the Fact that the difference is very small.  0.0912463180000032o or 0o 5' 28.4867448000115"   But I guess that is not 0  I was thinking it was rounding error.

The departure burn calculator is giving me a burn with an excessive amount of normal/antinormal delta v that is giving me an unusable result that doesn't match the porkchop plot delta v. Image attached, using latest version.

http://imgur.com/fDFvQyW
Any plans for a Linux port? Matlab is on Linux, but I'm not very familiar with it.

On 2016/02/11 at 1:57 AM, dlrk said:

The departure burn calculator is giving me a burn with an excessive amount of normal/antinormal delta v that is giving me an unusable result that doesn't match the porkchop plot delta v. Image attached, using latest version.

http://imgur.com/fDFvQyW

It's a fairly simple problem. it's due to the RAAN and Inclination not matching between the porkchop plotter and the Mission Architect. The initial orbit in MA seems to be perfectly equatorial, meaning you have to do a plane change AND the departure burn. plane changes require a LOT of dV.

Make sure the initial orbit in MA has the same values as those you used to compute the departure burn. In fact, calculate the optimal launch before you launch your spacecraft, that way you can launch into the correct orbital plane from the start and save a lot of fuel.

Edited February 18, 2016 by ANWRocketMan

@Arrowstar have you ever seen this particular error before? I've skimmed the web and this thread, but haven't seen anything yet. 

The procedure entry point
?throw_exception_v4@internal@tbb@@YAXW4exception_id@12@@Z
could not be located in the dynamic link library C:\Program Files\MATLAB\MATLAB Compiler Runtime\v84\bin\win64\mlutil.dll.

I triple-checked the install directions and everything is matching up, and the file in question (mlutil.dll) does exist, and is in the correct location. Could it have been a fluke with the installation?

New to this mod, trying to figure out a flyby and return for an unmanned Eloo probe.

I'm year 4, day 281 in my game and I'm running into some funny issues with the transfer tool - after entering my earliest departure and arrival times (year 4, day 281) I get this warning: 

Smallest delta-v value in plot (16.054 km/s) is greater than the maximum plottable delta-v in the options (10.00000 km/s).  Set max plottable delta-v to new recommended value of 18 km/s?

<NO>

Maximum plottable delta-v has not been updated.   Your plot may look funny or wrong.

 

Are you telling me this program isn't smart enough to figure out an acceptable transfer time to other planets?  Isn't this the purpose of the program?  It works if I set it to Year 1 day 1.  I would hope that the program could tell me how long it takes to transfer to another planet, and not have to check Alexmoon's Launch Window Planner...

 

For the record, the table I have for a transfer to Eloo says it should use roughly 2,140 m/s of delta-V.  Alexmoon says ~2,000 m/s.

 

What gives?

Edited March 6, 2016 by zilfondel

On 3/6/2016 at 7:13 PM, zilfondel said:

Are you telling me this program isn't smart enough to figure out an acceptable transfer time to other planets?  Isn't this the purpose of the program?  It works if I set it to Year 1 day 1.  I would hope that the program could tell me how long it takes to transfer to another planet, and not have to check Alexmoon's Launch Window Planner...

 

For the record, the table I have for a transfer to Eloo says it should use roughly 2,140 m/s of delta-V.  Alexmoon says ~2,000 m/s.

Hey, sorry for the late reply, life has been busy lately. Your problem is that the amount of time needed to get to Eeloo is more than the default number of synotic periods.  Use the Edit -> Options menu on the main GUI to bump this number up to like 5-10 and see if that helps any.

Also, for the record, the snark in your comment is not a great way to encourage a developer to help...
